projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.head: The Masque of Augures
Quarto 1621-2 C. 39. c.34. Ashely 9 ••
div.p: The text of the masque is identical in both copies, but C. 39. c. 34 has on B4 ve ••… a final note of acknowledgements to Inigo Jones, Ferrabosco and Lanier. I know no other copy containing this note.

div.head: The Masque of Augures. 1621.
div.p: Gifford expressly laments the want of a quarto edition of this masque of Ben Jonson's. It is very rare. The only copy for sale for many years produced L 12 at Sotheby's two or three years ago.

div.stage: The first Antimasque hath for the Scene, The COVRT-BVTTRYHATCH.
div.p: The Presenters are from Saint KATHERINES.

sp.speaker: NOTCH.
sp.p: COme, now my head's in, Ile eu'n venter the whole. I ha seen the Lions ere now; and he that hath seene them, may see the King.

sp.speaker: SLVG.
sp.p: I thinke he may: but haue a care you goe not too high (neighbour NOTCH) least you chance to haue a Tally made of your pate, and be clawed with a cudgell. There is as much danger in going too neere the King, as the Lions.

sp.speaker: GROOM.
sp.p: Whether? whether now Gamsters? what is the businesse? the affaire? stop I beseech you.

sp.speaker: NOTCH.
sp.p:
This must be an Officer, or nothing, he is so peart, and briefe in his demands! a prettie man! and a prettie man is a little o'this side nothing. Howsoeuer,
we must not be daunted now. I am sure I am, a greater man then he out of the Court, and I haue lost nothing of my size since I came into it.

sp.speaker: GROOM.
sp.p: Hey-da! whats this! A hogshead of beere broke out of the Kings Buttry, or some Dutch hulke! whether are you bound? The wind is against you: you must backe: doe you know where you are?

sp.speaker: NOTCH.
sp.p: Yes Sir, if we be not mistaken, wee are at the Court, and would be very glad to speak with something of lesse authoritie, and more wit, that knowes a little, in the place.

sp.speaker: GROOME.
sp.p: Sir, I know as little as any man in the place: speake, what is your businesse? I am an Officer, GROOME of the REVELS; I may and must aske you.

sp.speaker: NOTCH.
sp.p: Be not too mustie Sir; our desire is onely to know, whether the Kings Maiestie and the Court expect any Disguise here to night.

sp.speaker: GROOM.
sp.p: Disguise! what meane you by that? do you thinke his Maiestie sits here to expect drunkards?

sp.speaker: NOTCH.
sp.p: No, if he did, I beleeue you would supply that place better, then you doe this. Disguise was the olde English word for a Masque Sir, before you were an Implement belonging to the REVELS.

sp.speaker: GROOM.
sp.p: There is no such word in the Office now, I assure you Sir: I haue seru'd heere Man and Boy a prentiship or twaine, and I should know. But (by what name soeuer you call it) heere will be a Masque, and shall be a Masque, when you and the rest of your Comrogues shall sit disguis'd in the stocks.

sp.speaker: NOTCH.
sp.p:
Sure, by your language, you were neuer meant for a Courtier, howsoeuer it hath been your ill fortune to bee taken out of the nest young: you are
some Constables Egge, some such Widgin of authoritie, you are so easily offended! Our comming was to shew our loues, Sir, and to make a little merry with his Maiestie to night, and wee haue brought a Masque with vs, if his Maiestie had not been better prouided.

sp.speaker: GROOME.
sp.p: Who you? you a Masque? why you stinke like so many bloat herrings newly taken out of the chimney! In the name of ignorance whence came you? or what are you? you haue beene hangd in the smoake sufficiently, that is smelt out already.

sp.speaker: NOTCH.
sp.p: Sir, we doe come from among the Brewhouses in Saint KATHERINS, that's true, there you haue smoak'd vs (the Docke comfort your nostrils) and wee may haue liued in a mist there, and so mist our purpose: but for mine owne part, I haue brought my properties with me to expresse what I am, the keyes of my calling hang heere at my girdle; and this, the register booke of my function, shewes me no lesse then a Clerke at all points, and a Brewers Clerke, and a Brewers head-Clerke.

sp.speaker: GROOM.
sp.p: A man of account Sir! I cry you mercy.

sp.speaker: SLVG.
sp.p: I Sir, I knew him a fine Merchant, a Merchant of hops, till all hopt into the water.

sp.speaker: NOTCH.
sp.p:
No more of that, what I haue bin, I haue bin: what I am, I am. I PETER NOTCH Clearke, hearing the CHRISTMAS Inuention was drawne dry at Court, and that neither the Kings POET, nor his ARCHITECT had wherewithall left to entertaine so much as a Baboone of qualitie, nor scarce the Welsh Embassador if hee should come there; out of my allegeance to wit, drew in some other friends, that haue as it were presumed out of our owne naturals, to fill vp the Vacuum with some pretty presentation, which wee
haue addrest, and conuei'd hither in a lighter at the general charge, and landed at the back-doore of the Buttery, through my neighbour SLVGS credit there.

sp.speaker: SLVG.
sp.p: A poore Lighterman Sir, one that hath had the honour sometimes to lay in the Kings Beere there, and I assure you I heard it in no worse place, then the very Buttry, for a certaine, there would be no Masque, and from such as could command a Iacke of Beere two or three.

sp.speaker: VAN.
sp.p: Dat is all true, exceeding true, de Inuentors be barren, lost, two, dre, vour mile, I know that from my selua: dey haue no ting, no ting van deir owne, but var dey take vrom de eard, or de zea, or de heauen, or de hell, or de restuan de vier elementen, de place a, dat be so common as de venche in de Burdello. Now, me vould bring in some daintie new ting, dat neuer vas, nor neuer sall be, in de rebus natura! dat has never van de mater, nor de vorme, nor de head, nor de voot, but is a mera deuisa of de braine—

sp.speaker: GROOM.
sp.p: Hey-da, what HANS FLVTTERKIN is this? what do's this Dutchman build, or talke of? Castles in the ayre?

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.p: He is no Dutchman Sir, he is a Brittaine borne, but hath learned to misuse his owne tongue in trauell, and now speaks all languages in ill English. A rare Artist he is Sir, & a Proiector of Masques. His proiect in ours, is, that wee should all come from the three dancing Beares, a famous Alehouse in Saint Katherines (you may hap know it Sir), hard by where the Priest fell in, which Alehouse is kept by a distrest Lady, whose name (for the honour of Knighthood) will not be knowne, yet shee is come in person, errant, to fill vp the aduenture with her two Women that draw drinke vnder her, Gentlewomen borne, all three I assure you.

sp.speaker: SLVG.
sp.p:
And were three of those Gentlewomen, that
should haue acted in that famous matter of Englands Ioy, in sixe hundred and three.

sp.speaker: LADY.
sp.p: What talke you of Englands Ioy, Gentlemen? you haue another matter in hand ywis, Englands Sport, if you can manage it. The poore Cattell yonder, are passing away the time with a cheat loafe and a bumbard, how will you dispose of them?

sp.speaker: GR.
sp.p: Cattell? what Cattell do's she meane?

sp.speaker: LADY.
sp.p: No worse then the Kings Game I assure you: Beares of quality and fashion, right Beares, true Beares!

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.p: A deuice, onely to expresse the place from whence we come (my Ladies house) for which we haue borrowed three very Beares, that (as her Ladiship aforesaid sayes) are well bred, and can dance to present the Signe, and the Beareward to stand for the Signe-post.

sp.speaker: GR.
sp.p: That is prety: but are you sure you haue sufficient Beares for the purpose?

sp.speaker: SLVG.
sp.p: Very sufficient Beares, as any are in the ground: and can dance at first sight, and play their owne tunes, if need bee. IOHN VRSON the Beareward offers to play them with any Citie-Dancers, christned, for a ground measure.

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.p: Marry, for lofty tricks, or dancing on the ropes, he will not vndertake: it is out of their element, he sayes. Sir, all our request is, since we are come, we may bee admitted, if not for a Masque, for an Antick Masque: and as we shall deserue therein, we desire to be returned with credit to the Buttry, from whence we came, for reward; or to the Porters Lodge, for our punishment.

sp.speaker: GR.
sp.p: To be whipt with your Beares? Well, I could bee willing to venter a good word in behalfe of the Game, if I were assured the aforesaid Game would be cleanly, and not fright the Ladies.

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.p: For that, Sir, the Bearward hath put in securitie, by warranting my Lady and her Women to dance the whole Changes with them in safety; and for their abusing the place, you shal not need to feare, for he hath giuen them a kind of diet-bread, to bind them, to their good behauiour.

sp.speaker: GR.
sp.p: Well, let them come: If you need one, Ile helpe you my selfe.

p.hi: How like you? how like you?

sp.speaker: GRO.
sp.p: Excellaunt. The Beares haue done learnedly, and sweetly.

sp.speaker: VAN.
sp.p: Tis no ting, tis no ting, vill you see some ting? Ick sall bring in de groat Turkschen, met all zin Bashawes, and zin dirty towsand Yanitsaries, met all zin Whooren, Eunuken, all met an auder, de Sofie van Persia, de Tartar Cham, met de groat King of Mogull, and make deir men, and deir horse, and deir elephanten be seene fight in de ayre, and hee all killen, and aliuen! and no sush ting. And al dis, met de ars, van de Catropricks, by de refleshie van de glassen.

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.p: O, he is an admirable Artist.

sp.speaker: SLVG.
sp.p: And a halfe Sir.

sp.speaker: GR.
sp.p: But where will he place his glasses?

sp.speaker: VAN.
sp.p: Fow, dat is all ean! as it be two, dree, vier, vife tousand mile of, Ick sall multipliren de vizioun, met an ander setret dat Ick heb. Spreck, vat vil you heben?

sp.speaker: GR.
sp.p: Good Sir put him toot, bid him doe something that is impossible: he will vndertake it, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.p: I do not like the Mogull, nor the great Turke, nor the Tartar, their names are somwhat too big for the roome: marry if he could shew vs some Country-plaiers strolling about in seuerall shires, without licence from the office; that would please, I know whom.

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.p: Or some Welsh Pilgrims.

sp.speaker: VAN.
sp.p: Pilgrim? Now you talke of de Pilgrim, it come in my head, Ick vill shew you all de whole braue Pilgrim o' de vorld: de Pilgrim dat go now, now, at de instant, two, dree, towsand mile to de great Mahomet, at de Mecha, or here, dere, euery where, make de fine Labyrints, and shew all de braue error in de vorld.

sp.speaker: SLVG.
sp.p: And shall we see it here?

p.hi: Yau, here, here, here in dis roome, dis very roome: vel, vat is dat to you, if Ick do de ting? vat an Diuell, vera boten Deuill?

sp.speaker: GR.
sp.p: Nay, good Sir be not angry.

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.p: Tis a disease that followes all excellent men, they cannot gouerne their passions, but let him alone, trie him one bout.

sp.speaker: GR.
sp.p: I would try him, but what has all this to doe with our Masque?

sp.speaker: VAN.
sp.p: O Sir, all de better, vor an Antick-masque, de more absurd it be, and vrom de purpose, it be euer all de better. If it goe from de nature of de ting, it is de more art, for dere is Art, and dere is Nature; you shall see. Hochos-pochos. Fabros Palabros.

div.head: The second Antimasque.
div.stage: Which is a perplex'd dance of straying, and deform'd Pilgrims, taking seuerall pathes, till with the opening of the light aboue, and breaking forth of APOLLO, they are all frighted away, and the Mayne Masque begins.

sp.l: IT is no Dreame, you all doe wake and see:
Behold, who comes! far-shooting PHOEBVS, he
That can both hurt, and heale; and with his voyce
Reare Townes, and make Societies reioyce;
That taught the Muses all their harmony;
And men the tunefull art of Augury;
APOLLO stoopes: and, when a God descends,
May Mortals thinke he hath no vulgar ends.
sp.stage: Being neare the earth, hee calls these persons following, who come forth, as from their Tombes.
sp.l: LINVS, and ORPHEVS, BRANCHVS, IDMON, all
My sacred sonnes, rise, at your Fathers call,
From your immortall graues, where sleepe, not death,
Yet binds your powers.

sp.speaker: LINVS.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: ORPHEVS.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: BRANCHVS.
sp.l: What sacred breath
Doth re-inspire vs!

sp.speaker: IDMON.
sp.l: Who is this we feele!

sp.speaker: PHOEMONOE.
sp.l: What heat creepes through me, as when burning steele
Is dipt in water!

sp.speaker: APOLLO.
sp.l: I, PHOEMONOE,
Thy Father PHAEBVS'S fury filleth thee;
Confesse my Godhead: once againe I call,
Let whole APOLLO enter in you all,
And follow me.

sp.speaker: CHORVS.
sp.l: We flye, we do not tread,
The Gods doe vse to rauish whom they lead.

div.stage: APOLLO, descended, shewes them where the King sits, and sings forward.

sp.speaker: APOLLO.
sp.l: Behold the loue and care of all the Gods,
King of the Ocean, and the happie Iles,
That whilst the world about him is at ods,
Sits crowned Lord here of himself, and smiles.—

sp.speaker: CHORVS.
sp.l: To see the erring mazes of Mankind,
Who seeke for that, doth punish them to find.

div.stage: Then he aduanceth with them to the King.

sp.speaker: APOLLO.
sp.l: Prince of thy peace, see what it is to loue
The powers aboue!
IOVE hath commanded me
To visit thee:
And in thine honour with my musick reare
A Colledge here
Of tune-full Augnrs, whose diuining skill
Shall waite thee still,
Aud be the Heralds of his highest will.
The worke is done,
And I haue made their President thy Sonne.
Great MARS too, on these nights,
Hath added Salian rites.
Yond, yond, afarre,
They closed in their Temple are,
And each one guided by a starre.

sp.speaker: CHORVS.
sp.l: Haste, haste, to meete them, and as they aduance,
Twixt euery dance,
Let vs interpret their prophetick trance.

div.stage: Here they fetch out the Masquers, and come before them with the Torch-bearers along the Stage, singing this full Song.

sp.speaker: APOLLO and CHORVS.
sp.l: Which way, and whence the lightning flew,
Or how it burned, bright, and blew,
Designe, and figure by your lights:
Then forth, and shew the seuerall flights
Your Birds haue made, or what the wing,
Or voyce in Augurie doth bring.
Which hand the Crow cry'd on, how high
The Vultur, or the Erne did flie,
What wing the Swan made, and the Doue,
The Storke, and which did get aboue:
Shew all the birds of food, or pray.
But passe by the vnlucky Iay,
The Night-Crow, Swallow, or the Kite,
Let those haue neither rite,
Nor part,
In this nights art.

div.head: The Torch-Bearers Dance.
div.stage: After which the AVGVRS lay by their staues, and dance their Entry. Which done, APOLLO, and the rest interpret the Augurie.

sp.speaker: APOLLO.
sp.l: The signes are lucky all, and right,
There hath not bin a voyce, or flight
Of ill presage.

sp.speaker: LINVS.
sp.l: The Bird that brings
Her Augury alone to Kings,
The Doue, hath flowne.

sp.speaker: ORPHEVS.
sp.l: And to thy peace
Addes Fortunes, and the Fates increase.

sp.speaker: BRANCHVS.
sp.l: MINERVA'S Hernshaw, and her Owle
Do both proclaime, thou shalt controle
The course of things,

sp.speaker: IDMON.
sp.l: As now they be,
With tumult carried:

sp.speaker: APOLLO.
sp.l: And liue free
From hatred, faction, or the feare
To blast the Oliue thou dost weare.

sp.speaker: CHORVS.
sp.l: More is behind which these doe long to showe,
And what the Gods to so great vertue owe.

sp.speaker: CHORVS.
sp.l: Still, still the Auspice is so good
We wish it were but vnderstood;
It euen puts APOLLO
To all his strengths of art to follow
The flights, and to diuine
What's meant by euery signe.
Thou canst not lesse be then the charge
Of euery Deitie,
That thus art left here to inlarge,
And shield their pietie!
Thy Neighbours at thy fortune long haue gaz'd,
But at thy wisedome all doe stand amaz'd,
And wish to be
O'recome, or gouerned by thee!
Safetie it selfe so sides thee where thou goest,
And Fate still offers what thou couet'st most!

div.head: The Reuels.
div.stage: After which, APOLLO goes vp to the King, and sings.

lg.l: DOe not expect to heare of all
Your good at once, least it forestall
Some things the Fates would haue conceal'd
From vs the Gods, least being reueal'd
It is enough your people learne
As well as strangers doe discerne
And that the princely AVGVR here, your Sonne,
Doe by the Fathers lights his courses runne.

sp.speaker: CHORVS.
sp.l: Him shall you see triumphing ouer all
Both foes, and vices: and your young, and tall
Nephewes, his sonnes, grow vp in your embraces,
To giue this Iland Princes, in long races.

div.stage: Here the Heauen opens, and IOVE, with the Senate of the Gods, is discouered, while APOLLO returnes to his seat, and ascending sings.

sp.speaker: APOLLO.
sp.l: See, heauen expecteth my returne,
The forked fire begins to burne,
IOVE beckons me to come.

sp.speaker: IOVE.
sp.l: Though PHOEBVS be the God of Arts,
He must not take on him all parts:
But leaue his Father some.

sp.speaker: APOLLO.
sp.l: My Arts are onely to obey,

sp.speaker: IOVE.
sp.l: And mine to sway.
IOVE is that One, whom first, midst, last you call,
The power that gouern's, and conserueth all;
Earth, Sea, and Ayre are subiect to our checke,
And Fate, with Heauen, moouing at our becke.
Till IOVE it ratifie,
It is no Augurie,
Though vtter'd by the mouth of DESTINIE.

sp.speaker: APOLLO.
sp.l: Deare Father, giue the signe, and seale it then.

sp.speaker: The EARTH riseth.
sp.l: It is the suit of EARTH, and Men.

sp.speaker: IOVE.
sp.l: What doe these mortals craue without our wrong.

sp.speaker: EARTH with the rest.
sp.l: That IOVE will lend vs this our Soueraigne, long.
Let our grand-children and not we
His want, or absence euer see.

sp.speaker: IOVE.
sp.l: Your wish is blest:
IOVE knocks his chin against his brest,
And firmes it with the rest.

sp.speaker: CHORVS.
sp.l: Sing then his fame, through all the orbes, in euen
Proportions, rising still from Earth to Heauen:
And of the lasting of it leaue to doubt,
The power of Time shall neuer put that out.

p.hi: This done, the whole Scene shuts, and the Masquers dance their last dance.

div.p: For the expression of this, I must stand; The inuention was diuided betwixt Mr. IONES,and mee. The SCENE, which your eye iudges, was wholly his, and worthy his place of the Kings Surueyour, and Architect, full of noble obseruation of Antiquitie, and high Presentment. The Musique compos'd by that excellent paire of Kinsemen, Mr. ALPHONSO FERRABOSCO and Mr. NICHOLAS LANIER.

closer.signed: An sint Musis & Apolline digna, penes vos esto. B. J.
